results.title: Simple multicellular animals: sponges, coelenterates and flatworms
results.brief_description: Begins with a study of volvox and then moves to sponges, coelenterates and flatworms as examples of multicellular animals. Covers anatomy, nerve structure, fading strategies and reproduction. No other credits available.
results.title_for_label: Simple multicellular animals: sponges, coelenterates and flatworms

results.title: Simple men
results.creator_credit: True Fiction Pictures, Ted Hope and Hal Hartley
results.brief_description: Two brothers are searching for their terrorist father who has escaped from goal. The trail leads them to a small town on Long Island where they meet a community of people who give them a refreshingly different view of their father. The ensuing complications between the brothers, as they battle to discover the truth of their family history, results in their confiding and falling in love with two very independent women. In order to defend their father’s honour, they all become involved in a battle with the police that leads to a surprising resolution. From this simple plot Hartley creates an eccentric film about history and relationships that challenges the viewer’s stereotypes of heterosexual romance. As is typical in Hartley’s work, the ensemble cast is universally excellent, including Martin Donovan, Robert Burke and Bill Sage. Special mention must go to Elina Lowensohn who plays a Romanian immigrant who falls in love with one of the brothers. The Godardian scene in which she leads a dance to Sonic Youth’s song “Cool Thing” is one of the film’s highlights. The musical score is excellent.

results.title: Simple machines: inclined planes and levers (3rd edition)
results.brief_description: Defines the principles of the lever and inclined plane families in everyday use. Describes the concept of work in terms of force and distance and shows how simple machines make work easier.
results.title_for_label: Simple machines: inclined planes and levers (3rd edition)

results.title: Simple machines using mechanical advantage
results.brief_description: Defines terms such as work, mechanical advantage, and simple machine. Also describes the six types of simple machines and their functions; the lever, the pulley, the inclines plane, the wedge and the wheel and axle. Explains how the use of a simple machine can help our lives, such as the crane by lifting objects from one place to another, the conveyer belt moving ore up- hill to a crusher or grain to a silo. We use simple machines in our everyday lives without being aware of it, unless we look.

results.title: Simple machines
results.brief_description: At the heart of every modern mechanical device is a machine that’s been in use for thousands of years. This video introduces students to the simple machines: the lever, the inclined plane, the wedge, the screw, the pulley, and the wheel and axle. Animation and live action illustrate the principles behind their usefulness. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s Guide included.

results.title: Simple looms. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson and John Gray
results.brief_description: A how-to-do it program intended to provide the viewer with the confidence, skill and interest to try it for themselves. Suggestions are given on how inspiration and ideas may be drawn from the natural world for weaving design themes.

results.title: Simple demonstrations with water
results.brief_description: Demonstrations to illustrate that water has surface tension which acts like a film over it, that water exerts pressure, and that water can produce a buoyant force.

results.title: Simple demonstrations with static electricity
results.brief_description: Demonstrates basic concepts of static electricity. Shows that friction can produce static electricity, that both positive and negative charges can be created, that identical charges repel and opposite charges attract, and that all matter is electrically charged.

results.title: Simple demonstrations with magnetism
results.brief_description: Interesting demonstrations and experiments explain and illustrate the basic concepts of magnetism: magnets can produce a force, magnets have poles, magnets can make other magnets, and the earth is a magnet. Many of the experiments can be repeated in the classroom, while others use equipment not available in most schools.
